The New York Times
Times Square
OFFICE OF
THE EDITOR OF
THE BOOK REVIEW
div1.p:
It is quite too bad if the brief note (the wording of which I confess having ) I sent you in reference to "Emerson's Wife" should lead you to believe that I sought to impose restrictions of any kind upon you. My sole interest was to inform you of the authorship. If my note was so unfortunately worded as
8
to suggest a favorable review against your judgement I am very sorry. I should much appreciate a note from you which will give the text of my letter. I have never sought to suggest, ever, that a reviewer should go wide of his frank opinion in the matter of a book. Books that are sent to you or to any other reviewer are sent to provoke the reviewer's candid view; the Review will print no
9
other kind. The last book of Mrs. Kelly's in the Review was criticized unsparingly, so you are the entire independence of our publication. There have been several instances in which I had preferred that a book be praised but the review sent in was far from favorable to it — yet the review was published just as written. I feel it no of which to say to a reviewer,
"I hope you can praise this book" or "I should like to read a favorable review of this if it be possible to write it," where it is my intention to publish the review whatever opinion it expresses. When I write you at any time about a book, do not construe it as filtering your hand in any way. Books sent you are, as you know, to be reviewed as you see fit.
